question: Problems in society can all be traced back to lack of religion.
Unions only serve to divide workers in the modern world.
Everyone in our nation should be religious.
All religions should be allowed to prosper.
To go against the wants of the majority is detrimental to any ruling body.
Instead of the government having power over the people, the people should have power over the government.
We should make strides towards the abolition of all punishment.
We should abolish prisons so rehabilitation may put in their place.
If you have nothing to hide, you've got nothing to fear.
Government surveillance and tracking should be used to benefit our citizenry.
We should support all separatist movements worldwide.
Our nation should be composed entirely of immigrants.
Each nation should be free to choose its own destiny.
Monopolies are good.
We should abolish anti-trust laws.
All decisions are the purely the result of environmental influences, uncontrollable factors, and past history
Every people group should be guaranteed self-determination in their own separate nation.
Emotions and feelings are far more valuable than facts and reasoning.
An ideology should be implemented peacefully.
There should be a country where anyone could easily immigrate to for better opportunities.
We must maintain cultural and ethnic diversity.
We should allow people to mostly do what they want and help them in case they harm themselves.
We should keep a military but not use it for our own benefit.
International aid is necessary.
Welfare is always good.
A centralized government is needed.
Economic centralization is the only way to have an efficient economy and we should further centralize our economy.
We should limit aspects of forceful coercion in our government such as regulation.
Both privatization and nationalization of companies are bad, we should not forcefully change who owns something.
A theocracy is preferable to secularism.
We shouldn't allow anyone in our society to be atheist.
All changes should be made by negotiating with others to agree to our ideas, not forcing them.
